Solomon Islands: Supporting the Implementation of 
the National Development Strategy

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A  key  aspect  of  effective  development  management  is  the  formulation  and 
implementation  of  a  national  development  strategy.  For  Solomon  Islands,  this  is  doubly 
important, because development challenges are daunting, and priorities must be set. During 
the  2011  country  programming  mission  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the 
Government  of  Solomon  Islands  requested  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  support 
implementation of the national development strategy (NDS) for 2011–2020.1 The proposed TA 
is a continuation of the previous TA, which supported the formulation of the NDS.2 It directly 
links to ADB’s country operations business plan 2012–2014 for Solomon Islands, is consistent 
with the direction of ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2010–2014 and Strategy 2020, and is coordinated 
with related ADB regional TA projects, including Building Capacity for Statistics in the Pacific 
and Pacific Economic Management.3 The government concurs with the TA's objectives, scope, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The TA 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since the country became independent in 1978, the well-being of the population has 
improved modestly. With one of the fastest-growing populations in the world (2.8% per annum 
during 2007–2009), Solomon Islands’ per capita income is the second lowest in the region. A 
period of pronounced political instability and conflict—―the ethnic tensions‖ from 1999 to 2003—
further increased poverty, weakened governance, interrupted delivery of essential services, 
and exacerbated social tensions. However, the post-conflict economic recovery, for which the 
regional assistance mission to Solomon Islands (RAMSI) provided support, has witnessed 
improved law and order and financial discipline. The government has undertaken a number of 
major reform initiatives, including those affecting telecommunications, state-owned enterprises, 
secured  transactions,  and  public  financial  management,  and  has  launched  a  companies 
registry. 
 
3.  Despite progress in recent years, the country continues to face a major challenge in 
providing job opportunities and basic services to a rapidly growing population. Moreover, the 
Solomon Islands economy was strongly affected by the global economic crisis. Gross domestic 
product growth averaged 7.3% per annum in 2004–2008. In 2009, gross domestic product 
contracted by 1.2%. Solomon Islands returned to positive growth of around 7.2% in 2010, with 
similar growth expected in 2011. While economic growth has rebounded quickly, medium-term 
growth prospects are uncertain. Logging resources, the country’s main export, are expected to 
be largely exhausted by the middle of the decade. The economy is also one of the most aid-
dependent in the world. 
 
4.  The overarching theme of the NDS is to build better lives for all Solomon Islanders. Its 
major  areas  of  focus  are  (i)  poverty  alleviation  and  provision  of  greater  benefits  and 
opportunities; (ii) support for the vulnerable; (iii) providing access to quality health care and

2   
combating malaria, HIV, and non-communicable and other diseases; and (iv) access to quality 
education for the entire population. The NDS also incorporates the principles of the Paris 
Declaration for Aid Effectiveness.  
 
5.  Development partners have provided assistance for strategy formulation for previous 
development  strategies  in  Solomon  Islands,  but  there  has  been  little  support  for  the 
implementation of these plans and strategies. RAMSI support has been concentrated in the 
Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT). This, together with weak capacity within the Ministry 
of  Development  Planning  and  Aid  Coordination  (MDPAC),  has  resulted  in  incomplete 
implementation and poor effectiveness of the plans. Previous experience in the Pacific has also 
shown  that  in  order  for  a  development  strategy  to  be  effective,  strong  links  need  to  be 
established  with  other  government  plans,  especially  annual  line-ministry  corporate  plans, 
provincial plans, and the annual budget.  
 
6.  The Provincial Government Support Programme has established provincial plans, within 
the context of longer-term provincial strategic plans, as 3-year rolling plans. The guidelines for 
the  ministerial  corporate  plans  require  core  3-year  rolling  plans  with  a  minimum  format 
encompassing policy context and financial requirements. At present, the corporate planning 
process has only minimal links with the NDS. Provincial and ministerial corporate plans are 
also prepared on a government-wide, 3-year time horizon. Development budgets include 3-
year forward projections, which need to be strengthened. Sector plans have been prepared in 
key areas including health, education and transport infrastructure (the National Transport Plan). 
The linkage between the NDS, the budget, and the sector and provincial plans needs to be 
strengthened.  
 
7.  Typically, the government-funded portion of the development budget is about 20% of 
total development spending. In the existing budget process, implementing agencies receive 
short notice of activities to be funded. As a result, on average, almost half of the government 
development budget goes unspent. 
 
8.  The government plans to address this situation by having the MOFT develop a 4-year 
rolling medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) to better inform the planning activities of 
ministries and provinces in their 3-year rolling corporate and provincial plans. An MTEF is 
designed to link planning, which has a medium-term outlook, with the annual budget. As a 
consequence, budgetary expenditures are linked more systematically with target outcomes 
(e.g., increased economic growth, increased employment, gender balance, slower population 
growth, higher literacy rates, lower infant mortality rates). The MTEF’s principal focus is on 
incentivizing  the  government  to  allocate  budgetary  resources  to  programs,  activities,  and 
projects that promote the country’s strategic priorities. The preparation of an MTEF and its 
integration with the NDS will require further development of technical and human resources 
capability for forecasting and policy analysis. Further TA support is required to develop this 
capability in Solomon Islands, particularly given the planned drawdown of resident RAMSI 
advisors from 2012. 
 
9.  With ministerial corporate and provincial plans thus strengthened by the MTEF, the 
present 3-year projections included in the annual development budget can be converted into a 
3-year rolling medium-term implementation plan. This would incorporate a 3-year development 
budget, with details of development programs and projects, and an annual NDS performance 
evaluation report.  
 
10.  The aid management and coordination unit in MDPAC is responsible for coordinating

3 
with  the  government’s  development  partners  to  fund  programs  and  update  the  annual 
development budget. The budget is not regularly updated, and when it is, it is completed on an 
ad hoc basis. The updated annual development budget is then circulated to all ministries and 
line  agencies,  but  the  response  rate  has  been  disappointing.  Tracking,  monitoring,  and 
evaluating externally assisted projects are likewise done irregularly. A monitoring system needs 
to be developed to manage public investment information effectively, to promote accurate, 
timely  information,  and  to  ensure  that  evaluation  of  policies  and  program  outcomes  is 
communicated back to the line agencies and ministries. Ongoing monitoring and evaluation of 
progress against the NDS will be instrumental to successful NDS implementation and will be 
reflected in the annual NDS performance evaluation report. 
 
11.  Implementation of the NDS will make considerable demands on  MDPAC staff and 
sector planners in relevant line ministries, including MOFT and the Bureau for Economic and 
Social  Reform.  Specific  capacity  development  needs  will  include  strategic  development 
planning,  sector  analysis,  and monitoring  and evaluation.  This  can  be  addressed through 
capacity-building support for (i) mentoring and skills transfer through on-the-job training; (ii) 
designing and implementing short-term training, including training of trainers; and (iii) designing 
a medium-term training program for skills retention. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact will be the achievement of sustainable pro-poor growth through effective 
policy reform and strategy implementation. The outcome will be improved public expenditures 
and policies as a result of a strengthened development planning process.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will support the government in implementing a long-term strategic vision for 
achieving higher sustainable growth. The TA will help translate this vision into results-oriented 
objectives and targets within a medium-term expenditure framework, annual budgets, 3-year 
rolling implementation plans, and ministerial corporate plans. The TA will also improve capacity 
in strategic development planning and macroeconomic and policy analysis to enhance planning 
processes with sound policy advice. The TA will entail the following key components: 
 
(i)  Development of an MTEF to link the annual budgets with the NDS. The MTEF 
will also improve macroeconomic management by supporting a move toward 
medium-term budgeting; 
 
(ii)  Formulation  of  rolling  3-year  implementation  plans  that  implement  and  track 
progress against the NDS. These plans will draw on the corporate plans of all the 
ministries and reflect government policies and priorities. Support will also be 
provided  to  line  ministries  for  the  development  of  corporate  plans  that  are 
consistent with the NDS;  
 
(iii)  Strengthening  of  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  NDS  implementation  by  (a) 
developing databases and templates to track progress against the indicators of 
the NDS, and (b) producing an annual progress report on NDS implementation 
that will feed into the 3-year rolling implementation plans; and

4   
(iv)  Enhancement of the capacity of MDPAC staff and sector planners in relevant line 
ministries, including MOFT and the Bureau for Economic and Social Reform with 
regard to strategic development planning, sector analysis, and monitoring and 
evaluation  by  (a)  providing  mentoring  and  skills  transfer  through  on-the-job 
training; (b) designing and implementing short-term training, including training of 
trainers; and (c) designing a medium-term training program for skills retention. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The government has requested ADB to finance $600,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff salaries, office 
accommodation and transport, support services, and the facilitation of consultations. Details of 
the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2012 until January 2014. 
MOFT will be the executing agency and MDPAC will be the implementing agency. MDPAC will 
be responsible for the focused reforms envisaged in the TA. The MOFT has administrative 
authority within the government for all TA components. To facilitate communication between the 
implementing and executing agencies, a project coordination committee will be established, 
chaired by the permanent secretary of MDPAC. Both MOFT and MDPAC will provide office 
space for consultants and assign a senior counterpart staff member to lead the operational 
aspects of the reform process. The public will participate through extensive consultations with 
key  organizations  and  individuals  comprising  the  project’s  stakeholder  group.  In  addition, 
seminars will be organized to discuss the implementation of the project.  
 
16.  Consulting services of a total of 36 person-months (14 person-months international, 22 
person-months national) will be required for the implementation of the TA. The outline terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be selected in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement will be carried out 
in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All 
equipment procured under the TA will be turned over to the implementing agency at the end of 
the TA. 
 
17.  The Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office will administer the TA. Progress will be 
monitored using the intended outcome and outputs described in the design and monitoring 
framework in Appendix 1. Good practices and lessons will be disseminated through training 
sessions and workshops, and through TA reports. 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Solomon  Islands  for  Supporting  the  Implementation  of  the  National 
Development Strategy, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8                Appendix 3             
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants 
1.  Senior public finance economist—team leader (1 international, 10 person-
months) 
1.  The senior public finance economist and team leader will be a qualified economist with 
over 15 years of experience in a public finance role and in public investment planning, project 
management,  and  aid  management  and  budgeting.  Experience  gained  from  working  in  a 
ministry of finance (or equivalent) in a capacity development role is highly desirable. Experience 
with Pacific islands or small states would be an asset.   
 
2.  Working closely with Ministry of Development Planning and Aid Coordination (MDPAC) 
and Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT) staff, the expert will have overall responsibility for 
implementing the national development strategy (NDS) for 2010–2020. Integral to this role will 
be the provision of training, knowledge transfer, and mentoring. Specifically, the expert will: 
 
(i)  prepare a time-bound detailed technical implementation work plan, including a 
training  program  with  clear  milestones,  in  close  consultation  with  MDPAC. 
Support MDPAC and relevant line ministries to prepare and implement seminars 
and workshops; 
(ii)  help  MDPAC  develop  realistic  target  indicators  under  an  appropriate  results 
framework in order to utilize the NDS as a suitable mechanism for management 
of development results; 
(iii)  assist and strengthen the capacity of MDPAC and relevant line ministries to 
monitor (a) progress in achieving specific performance indicators, and (b) overall 
economic performance at macro and sector levels. This will include monitoring of 
NDS progress by preparing an annual monitoring and evaluation report; 
(iv)  support MDPAC and line ministries in the preparation of annual rolling 3-year 
implementation plans for the NDS; 
(v)  support  and  strengthen  the  capacity  of  staff  in  MDPAC  and  relevant  line 
ministries, including the MOFT and the Bureau for Economic and Social Reform, 
in preparation of corporate plans;  
(vi)  assist in designing and conducting relevant training for MDPAC staff in strategic 
development planning, sector analysis, and monitoring and evaluation, including 
a training of trainers program; 
(vii)   assist  in  developing  a  medium-  to  long-term  training  program  for  the 
government’s consideration; and 
(viii)  provide regular progress reports to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the 
government in accordance with the technical assistance (TA) implementation 
work plan. 
 
2.  Public finance economist (1 international, 4 person-months) 
3.  The  public  finance  economist  will  be  a  qualified  economist  with  over  15  years  of 
experience in a public finance role, and be experienced in budget formulation, implementation, 
and monitoring. Experience gained from working in a ministry of finance (or equivalent) in a 
capacity development role is highly desirable. Experience with Pacific islands or small states 
would be an asset.

Appendix 3  9 
4.  Working under the guidance of the team leader, the expert will assist the team leader 
with implementing the NDS 2010–2020. Working closely with MDPAC and MOFT staff, the 
expert will: 
 
(i)  develop a simple and cost-effective methodology for preparing the medium-term 
expenditure framework (MTEF), with an emphasis on establishing links between 
the NDS, annual budgets, and the MTEF;  
(ii)  develop a template that can be used for production of the MTEF on an annual 
basis; 
(iii)  identify  gaps  in  other  key  economic  statistics  critical  for  this  analysis,  and 
develop a simple and cost-effective methodology for their preparation; 
(iv)  provide  advisory  and  hands-on  training  to  build  the  capacity  of  MOFT  and 
relevant agencies to prepare the framework on a sustainable basis; and 
(v)  prepare detailed documentation and manuals, as needed, to institutionalize the 
new techniques and methodologies. 
 
3.  Planning specialists (2–3 national, 22 person-months total) 
 
5.  The planning specialists will be qualified economists or sector planners with over 10 
years  of  experience  in  a  public  finance  role,  and  be  experienced  in  budget  formulation, 
implementation, and monitoring. Experience gained from working in a ministry of finance (or 
equivalent) in a capacity development role is highly desirable. The specialists will be required to 
work closely with MDPAC, MOFT, and line ministries to enhance the budget process. The 
specialists will be required to implement TA activities while the international consultants are not 
in the country.  
 
6.  Working under the guidance of the team leader, the locally hired planning specialists will 
assist the international consultants with implementing the NDS 2010–2020. Specifically, they 
will: 
 
(i)  work  closely  with  the  international  consultants  and  MDPAC  to  develop  and 
implement  training  programs  as  directed  by  the  team  leader,  including 
conducting a training needs assessment; 
(ii)  administer workshops and seminars to be liquidated under the fund; 
(iii)  assist  MDPAC  and  the  team  leader  in  managing  and  liquidating  funds  for 
procurement  of  equipment,  information  technology  development,  training, 
seminars, and workshops; 
(iv)  Assist MDPAC in liaising and consulting with stakeholders on the implementation 
of the NDS; 
(v)  assist MDPAC in corporate planning to implement the NDS, including developing 
a new corporate structure for the NDS. 
(vi)  support  MDPAC  and  the  international  consultants  in  preparing  the 
implementation plans through 
(a)  preparing monitoring and evaluation reports;  
(b)  coordinating inputs from the budget, sector, and corporate plans; 
(c)  assisting  in  the  drafting  of  sections  of  the  implementation  plans  as 
necessary; 
(vii)  liaise with and assist line departments in the production of corporate plans; and 
(viii)  provide  ground  support  to  the  international  consultants  and  MDPAC  in 
implementing the four TA components.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
B.  Reporting 
 
7.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2012 until January 2014, with 
intermittent inputs from the international and national consultants.  
 
8.  The team leader will submit an inception report, including a detailed work plan and 
conceptual issues relevant to project delivery, 6 weeks after commencement of the TA. An 
interim  report  containing  the  first  draft,  which  includes  the  main  TA  components,  will  be 
submitted within 6 months of commencement of the TA. A midterm report, containing the final 
draft of the main TA components and the work program for continued training and additional 
follow-up work, will be submitted within 12 months of commencement of the TA. The team 
leader will submit progress reports after each field visit. A comprehensive draft final report will 
be submitted within 6 weeks of the final tripartite meeting. A final report will be submitted 4 
weeks after receipt of comments by ADB and government counterparts.
